title: UK Census Longitudinal Study Development Hub
abstractText:
In response to a recent independent evaluation of the ESRC Census Programme, a new UK Census Longitudinal Study Development Hub is being commissioned to co-ordinate and harmonise the work of the three Research Support Units supporting the England and Wales Longitudinal Study, Scottish Longitudinal Study and Northern Ireland Longitudinal Study.

The Hub also has a key objective of working towards the development of a single UK-wide Longitudinal Study (UKLS).

The Development Hub will have 9 core aims and objectives, namely to:

  1. actively take steps to drive forward the ambition of a UK Longitudinal Study
  2. promote the impact of the Census Longitudinal Studies
  3. deliver a single portal function to the Census Longitudinal Studies
  4. harmonise online tools, documentation and guidance, where possible
  5. deliver a single helpdesk for responding to generic queries
  6. plan and co-ordinate training and outreach activities
  7. engage with other related organisations in the UK and overseas to stimulate the most efficient delivery of the service
  8. develop and maintain a distinctive identity of the service, in collaboration with the UK Data Service
  9. establish and manage a Scientific Advisory Network.
impactText:
CALLS Hub was set up to support, promote and harmonise the work of the three census-linked UK Longitudinal Studies. These provide a unique and powerful research resource for a diverse range of academic disciplines as can be seen from our list of outputs. They also form a powerful source of research evidence for policy-makers, practitioners and third sector bodies.

CALLS Hub exists to help users and potential users find the information and resources they need in a straightforward way, and promote the work and impact of the RSU's to a wider audience.

Our website and helpdesk form a one-stop portal for researchers interested in using the Longitudinal Studies for their analyses. By bringing together the three studies, we can also highlight the potential benefits and opportunities of using more than one LS for research, either to provide a comparison of regional differences, or to expand the study population to ensure that results can be generalised to the whole country. findingsText: The nature of the investment is to support research infrastructure and in particular to support access to census-linked data sets If researchers succeed in comparing data across the UK's three longitudinal data sets, then this will significantly increase the value of the resource and will produce new findings in demography, health care, education, occupational and social mobility and many other fields.
